title: How to Make Nut Milk

steps.headline: Combine 1 cup of raw nuts and water in a large bowl.
steps.description: Soaking the nuts in water will make your milk creamier and easier to digest. Measure 1 cup (100 grams) of raw nuts into a bowl. Cover the nuts with approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) of tap water. Use raw nuts if you can. These will last longer and make a fresher tasting milk. Almonds, cashews, and peanuts are popular and delicious choices. Use 1 type of nuts or try combining different types of nut to create a unique tasting milk.

steps.headline: Leave the nuts to soak overnight.
steps.description: Place a tea towel over the bowl to avoid flies or dust contaminating the nuts. Leave the nuts to soak overnight out on the kitchen counter at room temperature or for up to 2 days in the fridge. Larger nuts will require more soaking time than smaller nuts. Peanuts can absorb water in just 6 hours, whereas, large cashews need at least 12 hours. If you are using a variety of nuts, don’t worry about the different times as you can’t over-soak the nuts.

steps.headline: Place the nuts into a strainer and rinse them with water.
steps.description: Carefully pour the nuts into a strainer or colander. This will allow the water to drain off the nuts. While the nuts are in the strainer, place them under the cold tap to rinse them. Rinse the nuts for 30 seconds and then tap the strainer to remove any excess water.

steps.headline: Place the nuts and 2 cups (470 mL) of water into a blender.
steps.description: Transfer the soaked nuts from the strainer to the blender. Measure 2 cups (470 mL) of water into the blender. If you don’t have a blender, a food processor will also work, however, a blender will make creamier and richer milk.

steps.headline: Blend the nuts and water for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Pulse the blender a couple of times to slightly crush the nuts and then turn the blender to the highest speed for 3 minutes. This will break the nuts down into a fine meal and the water will turn white. If you are using a food processor instead of a blender, blend the mixture for 4 minutes in total. You will need to stop the machine a few times to scrape the mixture off the sides.

steps.headline: Strain the ground nuts out of the liquid.
steps.description: Line your strainer or colander with 2 layers of cheesecloth or a nut bag. Place the strainer over a bowl and carefully tip the nut mixture into the strainer. Gather the edges of the cloth to form a bag and squeeze the meal to remove milk . Choose a bowl that is large enough to hold about 2 cups (470 mL) of milk. Place the leftover nut meal into ice cube trays and put it in the freezer. Use the meal as a delicious and nutritious addition to smoothies or baking at a later.

steps.headline: Taste the milk and add a sweetener if you prefer a richer taste.
steps.description: Taste the milk with a clean spoon. If it isn’t sweet enough, add a few drops of your favourite sweetener. Mix the sweetener into the milk and then taste it again. Continue to add sweetener until you are happy with the taste. Honey, maple syrup, agave sweetener, and stevia are good sweetener options. These can be purchased from a health store.

steps.headline: Serve the milk chilled or use it for baking.
steps.description: Nut milk tastes best when it is drunk chilled. Leave the milk in the fridge for 30 minutes to cool before drinking. Alternatively, use the milk in your hot drinks, baking, cereal, or smoothies. Nut milk is a great substitute for any recipes that require regular milk. This is a great option if you are intolerant to dairy.

steps.headline: Keep the milk in the fridge for up to 4 days.
steps.description: Pour the nut milk into an airtight container and leave it in the fridge. Drink the milk within 4 days. If the milk has separated when you come to drink it, stir it vigorously to recombine the liquid. If you want to store the milk for longer, place the airtight container in the freezer for up to 1 month. Place the container in the fridge to thaw.
